attributes.title: Correlates of the Short Dark Tetrad (SD4) Scale
attributes.description: We strive to validate a German version of the Short Dark Tetrad Scale (SD4)

q1.value: Correlates of the Short Dark Tetrad (SD4) Scale

q3.value:
The present study aims to investigate the nomological network of the German ver-sion of the Short Dark Tetrad (SD4; Paulhus, Buckels, Trapnell & Jones, 2020). The SD4 is a recently developed personality questionnaire that measures the four antagonistic personality traits narcissism, Machiavellianism (Mach), psychopathy and sadism. Grandiose narcissism is characterized by a sense of entitlement, grandiose exhibition, and an overestimation of own skills and achievements. It must be distinguished from vulnerable narcissism which is neither part of the Dark Tetrad nor of this study. Grandiose narcissism is nonpathological whereas vulnerable narcissism describes a clinical pattern (Krizan & Herlache, 2017; Wink, 1991). Psychopathy consists of callous, highly impulsive, thrill-seeking behavior and low anxiety. Further features are lack of remorse, a tendency of lying and deceiving, an antisocial orientation, egocentricity and violence. Central characteristics of Mach are coldness and manipulativeness. It can be understood as an exploitive, unprincipled, reasoned and calculat-ing trait, including planning or forming coalitions in order to achieve one’s goals. Sadism is characterized by the pleasure derived from distress or harm of others. It includes cruelty in daily actions and entertainment in general, e.g., violent films, sports or video games (cf. Baumeister & Campbell, 1999; Book, Visser & Volk, 2015; Book et al., 2016; Chabrol, van Leeuwen, Rodgers & Séjourné, 2009; Paulhus & Williams, 2002). Research has shown cer-tain overlaps between the four Dark Tetrad traits leading to difficulties in separating them (e.g., Međedović & Petrovic, 2015; Paulhus & Williams, 2002). Thus, in hypothesizing, we strive to contribute to a better differentiation between the traits. All four Dark Tetrad mem-bers are meant to describe non-pathological traits that are found in the normal population (Jones & Weiser, 2014; Međedović & Petrovic, 2015). 
We will validate the SD4 by investigating associations with other measures of the Dark Tetrad traits, other personality traits, clinical traits, impulsivity, aggression, personal values, motives, social orientations (dominance, prestige and leadership, sexual behavior), the interpersonal circumplex and self-esteem (for the relevance of this, see Kajonius, Persson, Rosenberg & Garcia, 2016; Spain, Harms & LeBreton, 2014).

q4.value: The hypotheses regarding the nomological networks and the expected effects' magnitudes are depicted in the document "Pre-registration SD4".

question.value:
Participants will be recruited at universities and via social media for an online sur-vey on Unipark. A brief description of the study’s aims will inform to examine a question-naire regarding certain personality traits. Participants will be told they would have to process several statements on their personality for about 20 minutes. The only inclusion criterion is the age of at least 18 years. A lottery for one out of ten 25 €-shopping vouchers and scientifi-cally based feedback on personality (Big Five) will serve as incentive system. Students of psychology and sports sciences will further be incentivized to participate by receiving study relevant credits. Each participant will respond to demographics (age, gender, educational level), language skills, SD4, the Big Five Inventory (BFI-2; Danner et al., 2016), and one of two sets of other questionnaires (see below). Language skills will be obtained in order to conduct robustness checks without participants who indicated low language skills. After all items are administered, participants will automatically receive feedback on their personality, will be invited to enter comments and will be redirected to a separated lottery page. Psychol-ogy and sports sciences students will be especially linked to a separate page in order to re-ceive their study-relevant credits. In the end, a text will thank for participating and inform about the study’s goals in more detail.
To determine the target sample size, we refer to Schönbrodt and Perugini (2013). They examined the effects of the sample size for correlational analyses and stated a mini-mum of 250 subjects is needed in order to stabilize the coefficients and the significance tests. As we aim a broad-based validation with several criteria, implying a magnitude of items and greater load for participants, we decided to split the item pool and the sample. Thus, to re-duce the number of items for each participant, subjects will be randomly assigned to one of two conditions. In Condition 1, participants will complete the PID-5-BF (Zimmermann et al., 2014), the Unified Motives Scale (Schönbrodt & Gerstenberg, 2012), the short form of the NARQ (NARQ-S; Leckelt et al., 2018), M7 and P7 (Grosz et al., in prep.), personal values (GESIS, 2014), the short form of the Interpersonal Adjective List (IAL-K; Jacobs & Scholl, 2016), the short form of the UPPS-P Impulsive Behaviour Scale (Keye et al., 2009) and posi-tive urgency (Cyders et al., 2014; Cyders, Smith, Spillane, Fischer, Annus and Peterson, 2007). In Condition 2, participants will complete the Aggression Scale (Werner & von Col-lani, 2014), the VAST (Paulhus & Jones, 2014), the NPI-13 (Brailovskaia et al., 2019), the short form of the SRP-III (Gordts et al., 2015), the Mach-IV (Henning & Six, 1977), the Dominance, Prestige, and Leadership scales (DoPL; Suessenbach et al., 2019), the Honesty-Humility scale from the HEXACO-60 (Moshagen et al., 2014), the Rosenberg Self-Esteem scale (von Collani & Herzberg, 2003), and the Revised Sociosexual Orientation Inventory (SOI-R; Penke, 2011). Thus, in addition to the “core items” (SD4, BFI-2, demographics, lan-guage skills), additional 133 and 136 items are presented in condition 1 and condition 2, re-spectively. Following Schönbrodt and Perugini’s suggestion, we aim to have at least 250 participants in each of the two conditions. In order to address and compensate dropout and missing data at the outset, we aim to recruit 600 participants in total (i.e., in both conditions combined). In case of missing data, we will apply pairwise deletion.

question.value: no manipulation

We will validate SD4-Narcissism, -Psychopathy, -Machiavellianism and -Sadism (seven items, each; 1 = strongly disagree, 2 = disagree,  3 = neutral, 4 = agree, 5 = strongly agree) with the Narcissistic Personality Inventory (13 Forced Choice Items), a short form of the Narcissistic Admiration and Rivalry Questionnaire (three items for admiration and rivalry, each; 1 = does not apply at all, 6 = applies perfectly), the P7 (seven items, 1 = disagree strongly, 2 = disagree, 3 = neither agree nor disagree, 4 = agree, 5 = agree strongly), a short form of the Self-Report Psychopathy Scale III (28 items, 1 = disagree strongly, 5 = agree strongly), a German version of the Mach-IV (20 items, -3 = Strongly Disagree, +3 = Strongly Agree; neutral anchor 0 left out), the M7 (seven items, 1 = disagree strongly, 2 = disagree, 3 = neither agree nor disagree, 4 = agree, 5 = agree strongly), a German translation of the VAST (16 items, 1 = strongly disagree, 5 = strongly agree), a German version of the Big Five Inventory-2 (60 items, 1 = disagree at all, 2 = rather disagree, 3 = in part, 4 = rather agree, 5 = fully agree), a German version of the Honesty-Humility scale (ten items, 1 = completely disagree, 5 = completely agree), the German version of the PID-5-BF (25 items, 0 = does not apply at all, 1 = rather not applicable, 2 = rather applicable, 3 = applies exactly), a German version of the Brief UPPS Impulsive Behavior Scales (20 items, 1 = strong disagreement, 2 = disagreement, 3 = neutral, 4 = agreement, 5 = strong agreement), German translations for the positive urgency scale (Cyders et al., 2014) and Cyders et al.’s (2007) item “When I am very happy, I feel like it is OK to give in to cravings or overindulge” (total of five items, 1 = strong disagreement, 2 = disagreement, 3 = neutral, 4 = agreement, 5 = strong agreement), a German version of the aggression scale (12 items, 1 = not applicable, 4 = fully applicable), a German version of the Personal Values scale (17 items, 1 = not like me at all, 6 = very much like me), the German version of the Unified Motives Scale (12 items, 0 = strongly disagree / not important to me, 1 = disagree / of little importance to me, 2 = ra-ther disagree / of some importance to me, 3 = rather agree / important to me, 4 = agree / very important to me, 5 = strongly agree / extremely important to me), the German Interpersonal Adjective List (34 items, 1 = extremely inaccurate, 8 = extremely accurate), the German DoPL scales (18 items, 1 = does not apply at all / Not important to me, 6 = applies perfectly / Extremely important to me), the German Sociosexual Orientation Inventory-Revised (nine items, 1 = 0 / never / strongly disagree, 2 = 1 / very seldom, 3 = 2 to 3 / once a month, 4 = 4 to 7 / once a week, 5 = 8 or more / nearly every day / strongly agree) and the German version of the Rosenberg Self-Esteem scale (ten items, 0 = does not apply at all, 3 = applies completely).

The validation is based on the correlations of the unweighted mean scores of the SD4-traits and the unweighted mean scores of the criteria.
The construct validation is further based on equivalence tests and profile similarity analysis. Both procedures and their respective applications are explained in the document "Pre-registration SD4".

To investigate the nomological network of the four SD4 scales, we will calculate the bivariate product-moment correlation between the unweighted mean of each SD4 scale and the unweighted mean of each scale of the nomological network (Table 1). To test the hy-potheses concerning the nomological networks, we will use equivalence testing (Lakens, 2017; Lakens, Scheel & Isager, 2018) and profile similarity analysis (Furr & Heuckeroth, 2019).

q20.value:
Several reversed-coded items will be re-reversed before the analyses.
Since our assessment system (Unipark) does not support some of the original scales' anchors (e.g., code 0 is not supported), we transform the Unipark-codes (e.g., 1, 2, 3, 4, 5) to the original codes (e.g., 0, 1, 2, 3, 4), if necessary.

q21.value:
We will use one-sided tests for convergent validation (e.g., SD4-Narcissism and other narcissism scales). Correlations should be greater than r = .60.
For other measures, we use two one-sided tests in order to ensure that an empirical correlation lies within pre-determined equivalence bounds. The procedure of equivalence testing is defined in the document "Pre-registration SD4".

Profile similarity analysis enables us to consider the roles of all constructs in the nomologi-cal network simultaneously, i.e., to quantify the congruence between hypothesized (Table 1) and empirical nomological networks. We will calculate the profile similarity for each SD4 trait separately, using the method Contrast-Construct Validity (CCV; Furr & Heuckeroth, 2019). That is, for each dark trait, we will transform the expected correlations to contrast weights and aggregate them with the Fisher z-transformed actual effects (for formulae and precise illustration of the mathematical background, see Furr & Heuckeroth, 2019).

q22.value:
Outliers will be included in the analysis.
No awareness checks are used.

q23.value: We apply pairwise deletion in case of missing data.

q24.value: We will test gender effects for the SD4 traits. Furthermore, we will conduct robustness checks concerning language skills.

attributes.title: ML5: Replications of Foerster et al. (2008)

summary.value: This is a registration of the project post-data collection.

registration_responses.summary: This is a registration of the project post-data collection.

q1.value: The aggression tolerance in the Hong Kong's anti-extradition protest

q3.value: The previous study showed that one experienced aversive events (i.e pain, heat, and goal blocked) and anger (i.e perceived injustice, thought of attack and elevated arousal), then aggression is likely. However, the predictors of one's violence tolerance remain unknown. Hence, the current study will measure whether the predictors (i.e pain, goal blocked, perceived injustice and elevated arousal) associated with violence tolerance of people.

q4.value:
(1) If the basic need of people is not satisfied,  it will be positively associated with the violence tolerance of people
(2) If one's group identity within a group is high, the violence tolerance towards that group would be higher. 
(3) If one perceives police violence as fair, the violence tolerance towards protesters would be lesser.
(4) If one was experiencing frustration, one would more likely act aggressively behavior and having higher violence tolerance.
(5)  If one was experiencing moral outrage on media, it would motivate one to shame and punish wrongdoers and having higher violence tolerance.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: The study is a correlational study design. The independent variable is the predictor of violence tolerance, including basic need satisfaction, perceived justice, psychological pain and elevated arousal by media outrage. The dependent variable is the violence tolerance of a person. The whole study would be conducted in Chinese, to enhance participants' understanding of questions.  180 participants would be recruited from the Internet. The participant needs to complete the questionnaire, it was assessed the basic need satisfaction, basic empathy, group identity, procedural justice, psychological pain, and violence tolerance.

q10.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

question.value: Participants will be recruited through the Internet and instant messaging app, i.e Portal, Whatsapp. Participants will be paid $20 for agreeing to participate in and completing the questionnaires. The data collection will be last for two weeks.

q13.value: In this study, the target sample size is 180 participants. We will attempt to recruit up to 200, assuming that some of them may not meet the requirements and uncomplete the total questionnaire.

q15.value: We will stop the data collection after publishing the questionnaire for two weeks.

question.value:
The outcome variables are group identity, procedural justice, empathy, basic need satisfaction, psychological pain, and violence tolerance. 

For the group identity, we will measure this by asking participants "How much do you identify with protestors of Anti-Extraction Law Amendment Bill Movement? " and "How much do you agree with the performance of the government?", the participants need to choose a scale of 1-7, 1 being "Strongly disagree", 7 being "Strongly agree".

For the perceived justice about Hong Kong policemen, we will measure this by using the Procedure Justice Scale. The participants need to choose a scale of 1-7, 1 being "Definitely not", 7 being "definitely yes" according to each statement of the Procedure Justice Scale.

attributes.title: The efficacy and safety of Banxia-Houpo-Tang for Chronic pharyngitis：Protocol for systematic review and meta-analysis

q1.value: The efficacy and safety of BHT for Chronic pharyngitis：Protocol for systematic review and meta-analysis

q4.value: BHT（Banxia-Houpo-Tang） has proven to be effective in the treatment of chronic pharyngitis, yet its real extent is not well understood. To prove this point, we will perform a protocol for a systematic review and meta-analysis of Banxia-Houpo-Tang for chronic pharyngitis

q5.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)

question.value: We will search for electronic databases both English and Chinese from inception to December 2019. Two experienced researchers select the qualified articles from：The Cochrane Library, EBM Reviews, OVID, Web of Science, PubMed, Chinese National Knowledge Infrastructure (CNKI), China Academic Journal Network Publishing Database (CAJD), China Biomedical Literature database (CBM), VIP Database for Chinese Technical Periodicals (VIP). Journal Integration Platform and WAN FANG Database.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Two experienced researchers select the qualified articles from：The Cochrane Library, EBM Reviews, OVID, Web of Science, PubMed, Chinese National Knowledge Infrastructure (CNKI), China Academic Journal Network Publishing Database (CAJD), China Biomedical Literature database (CBM), VIP Database for Chinese Technical Periodicals (VIP). Journal Integration Platform and WAN FANG Database. We select the appropriate searching language.

q13.value: All the clinic trials of prospective, randomized, multi-center, double-blind, parallel-group, placebo-control studies about BHT (or Chinese patent medicine for BHT) will be included.

question.value: The primary outcome was remission rate. Remission was defined as all the uncomfortable symptoms such as dry throat, sore throat, pharyngeal itching, dry cough, difficulty in swallowing are not recurrence in six months

Data statistics analysis will be performed using Review Manager 5.3 software (Cochrane Collaboration, Denmark) and Stata 14.0 (Stata Statistical Software: Release 14.Heterogeneity analysis was used to test whether the results of each independent study were combinable or not.If more than 10 standard-compliant studies are included, a funnel chart will be adopted to evaluate publication bias reports.Subgroup analysis is used to find the reasons for heterogeneity.

q1.value: Far Transfer of Online Cognitive Bias Modification for Negative Prospection: Effects on Anxiety and Performance During a Speech Stressor Task

q2.value: Jeremy William Eberle, Nauder Namaky, Bethany Teachman

q3.value: The present randomized controlled trial tested four online, at-home sessions of interpretation bias training designed to shift negative future thinking in college students. Treatment effects on expectancy bias, anxiety and depression symptoms, self-efficacy, growth mindset, and optimism from baseline to a 1-week, in-lab follow-up were reported by Namaky, Glenn, Eberle, and Teachman (2019). In the present analyses, we test treatment effects on affective forecasting and performance on a speech stressor task completed during the follow-up assessment.

q4.value:
Participants in the positive conditions (Positive Prospection, Positive Prospection + Negation) will have lower expected and actual anxiety during the speech, higher expected and perceived speech performance, higher observer-rated speech performance (i.e., better eye gaze, vocal tone, and speech flow; lower discomfort), and less avoidance behavior (i.e., longer speech duration) than those in the Neutral Control condition. Participants in the 50/50 condition will have intermediate results. We will compare the two positive conditions (Positive Prospection, Positive Prospection + Negation) but do not have directional hypotheses for this comparison; instead, we have competing hypotheses, given that the negation phrase may either improve efficacy by disconfirming negative expectations (Seligman et al., 2013) or reduce efficacy by reinforcing negative associations (Ouimet, Gawronski, & Dozois, 2009).

We will also conduct exploratory analyses of the effect of these conditions, making the same comparisons above, on affective forecasting accuracy and performance forecasting accuracy.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: Participants were randomized to either one of four conditions: Positive Prospection, Positive Prospection + Negation, 50/50, or Neutral Control. Participants were asked to complete two sessions per week for two weeks. Before starting the first session, participants were asked to complete, in random order, measures of expectancy bias, anxiety and depression symptoms, self-efficacy, growth mindset, and optimism. Participants were asked to complete the bias task, with the same stimuli, after every session except the first. Within one week after completing the fourth session, participants were asked to complete the follow-up, in which they completed the baseline measures again in random order. After completing these measures, they completed measures of their expected speech-related anxiety and expected speech performance and then measures of their actual anxiety and perceived speech performance following the speech.

q9.value: We assigned each participant to one of the four conditions using simple randomization with a sequence determined by freely available true-random software (Haahr, 1999).

q10.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

q11.value: Self-reported speech anxiety and self-reported speech performance (see Measured Variables below) were stored in different tables than those used to store data analyzed by Namaky et al. (2019). Speech recordings were accessed by Jeremy Eberle and Nauder Namaky to confirm their availability, identify audiovisual issues, and determine the number of codeable videos per condition. A research assistant, different from the research assistants who coded the videos, trimmed excess footage from the videos before and after the speech. Eberle, Namaky, and at least two other research assistants will code videos from a different study for training purposes. These research assistants will code the videos from the present study, with Eberle and Namaky providing supervision and analyzing ratings for the purpose of maintaining inter-rater reliability.

question.value: Students in the psychology department participant pool at a midatlantic university whose net expectancy bias scores (mean of positive bias items - mean of negative bias items) were more than 0.5 standard deviations below the mean of the sample (i.e., less than 1.11) and who were at least 18 years of age were eligible and invited by email to participate for course credit. The recruitment and data collection occurred between August 2015 and May 2016.

q13.value: 776 participants completed the Expectancy Bias Task during screening, 240 enrolled and were randomized to condition, 201 began the first session, 172 completed all four sessions, and 109 completed the in-lab follow-up assessment. Eighty-two have codeable speech videos. We will analyze data from 109 participants for self-reported anxiety (expected and actual) and speech performance (expected and perceived). We will analyze data from 82 participants for observer-rated speech performance and avoidance behavior.

q14.value: We will include all of the data collected during the study. A power analysis based on the mean effect size from a meta-analysis of the effect of cognitive bias modification on interpretation bias (g = 0.81; Hallion & Ruscio, 2011) revealed that, using an alpha-level of .05, a comparable Cohen’s f of .40 would result in a 100% likelihood of finding significant condition differences with 50 participants per condition. We enrolled 60 participants per condition because we anticipated some dropout.

question.value: The positive conditions presented emotionally ambiguous scenarios about the future that ended positively 100% of the time after first either negating a negative outcome (Positive Prospection + Negation) or not (Positive Prospection). The 50/50 condition presented emotionally ambiguous scenarios that ended positively 50% of the time and negatively 50% of the time. Neutral Control presented emotionally neutral scenarios. All conditions presented 48 scenarios per session.

Self-Reported Speech Anxiety
    Expected. Expected peak speech anxiety “during a 4-min speech that will be evaluated by a researcher” was assessed using the following 7-point Likert item ranging from 1 (not at all anxious) to 7 (totally anxious): “To what extent do you think you will experience anxiety during speech, when you feel the most anxious?”
    Actual. Actual peak speech anxiety “during the speech, at the height of [the] emotion” was assessed using the following 7-point Likert item ranging from 1 (not at all anxious) to 7 (totally anxious): “How anxious did you feel when you felt most anxious during the speech?”
    
Self-Reported Speech Performance
    Expected. Expected speech performance (“how you believe you will perform during the speech task based on a number of features”) was assessed with an adapted version of the Modified Perception of Speech Performance Questionnaire (MPSP; Cody & Teachman, 2011), a 12-item self-report of global and local speech performance features using 5-point Likert items ranging from 0 (not at all) to 4 (very much). Negative items will be reverse scored so that higher scores indicate better performance. We will analyze the mean of the items. Because the items are about expected speech performance, the tense of each item was changed accordingly from that used in Cody and Teachman (2011; e.g., “keeping eye contact” vs. “kept eye contact”).
    Perceived. Actual speech performance (“how you believe you actually performed during the speech task based on a number of features”) was assessed with the MPSP. As for expected speech performance, negative items will be reverse scored so that higher scores indicate better performance. We will analyze the mean of the items.

Observer-Rated Speech Performance. We will assess observer-related speech performance with an adapted version (Gorlin & Teachman, 2015) of Harb, Eng, Zaider, and Heimberg’s (2003) modified version of the Social Performance Rating Scale (SPRS; Fydrich, Chambless, Perry, Buergener, & Beazley, 1998). Coders will rate the quality of participants’ eye gaze, vocal tone, and speech flow on three 5-point Likert items ranging from 1 (very poor) to 5 (very good) and participants’ discomfort on a 5-point Likert item ranging from 1 (very high) to 5 (very low). We will analyze the mean of the items following Gorlin and Teachman (2015).

Avoidance Behavior. Avoidance behavior will be measured as the speech duration, defined as the number of seconds from the moment the research assistant gave the instruction to begin the speech to the end of the participant’s last word of the speech. We will operationalize avoidance behavior as fewer seconds spent on the speech.

Self-Reported Speech Performance. Following Cody and Teachman (2011), we analyzed the mean of the 12 items of the MPSP.

Observer-Rated Speech Performance. Following Gorlin and Teachman (2015) and Harb et al. (2003), we analyzed the mean of the four eye gaze, vocal tone, speech flow, and discomfort items as an overall anxious behavior index score.

We will test our hypotheses concerning the effect of condition on self-reported anxiety, self-reported speech performance, observer-rated speech performance, and avoidance behavior using linear regression models. In each model, the DV will consist of one variable of interest at one time point. The full list of DVs is as follows:

Expected speech anxiety
Peak speech anxiety
Expected speech performance
Perceived speech performance
Observer-rated speech performance
Avoidance behavior

The IV in each model will be condition, with specific contrasts set to test our hypotheses outlined above. The following contrasts will be used for all models:

Positive Prospection and Positive Prospection + Negation vs. Neutral Control (Hypothesis: "Participants in the positive conditions... will have lower expected and actual anxiety during the speech, higher expected and perceived speech performance, higher observer-rated speech performance... and less avoidance behavior... than those in the Neutral Control condition").

50/50 vs. Neutral Control (Hypothesis: "Participants in the 50/50 condition will have intermediate results.")

50/50 vs. Positive Prospection and Positive Prospection + Negation (Hypothesis: "Participants in the 50/50 condition will have intermediate results.")

Positive Prospection vs. Positive Prospection + Negation (Hypothesis: “We will compare the two positive conditions [Positive Prospection, Positive Prospection + Negation] but do not have directional hypotheses for this comparison; instead, we have competing hypotheses…”).

q20.value:
Condition: Condition will be dummy coded according to the contrasts outlined above.

Time: In affective forecasting analyses (see below), time will be coded with pre-speech ratings as 0 and post-speech ratings as 1.

All variables (except time) will be converted to standard scores (mean centered and divided by their respective standard deviations). This will be done to make effect sizes comparable between the models and to increase the likelihood of model convergence.

q21.value:
We will use an alpha level of .05 for determining significance. We will correct for multiple testing within each model using the method for family-wise correction outlined by Westfall et al. (1999). 

Exploratory models will also not be corrected for multiple comparison, in order to minimize the chance of false negatives. These findings will, therefore, be interpreted with caution and used to inform future, confirmatory studies.

q22.value: All participants with valid data will be included in the analysis. Valid data in the case of video coding means that a participant consented for video data to be used, and the video quality was such that the participant could be seen and heard by the raters. Valid data in the case of self-report data means that the participant answered the question when prompted.

q23.value: For item-level missingness on the MPSP, we will analyze the mean of the available items. If a participant did not complete any items of a given self-report measure, then they will not be included in the analysis of that measure. If a participant did not consent to the use of video data or was not visible or audible on their video, then they will not be included in the analysis of observer-rated speech performance.

q24.value:
To test our exploratory hypotheses concerning affective forecasting, we will use separate, hierarchical linear models for each dependent variable: self-reported speech anxiety and self-reported speech performance. Each of these variables will be a dependent variable in a model. Time, condition, and the time-by-condition interaction will be entered as fixed effects, and a random intercept per participant will be entered as the random effect. Independent variables will be considered sequentially in the model, with time and condition entered simultaneously at level 1 and their interaction entered at level 2. Level 1 results will only be analyzed in models with no significant time-by-condition interaction. The initial contrasts will compare all other groups to Neutral Control, but descriptive models will be run with each condition set as the reference group to characterize significant effects.

If any condition or time-by-condition effects are significant, follow-up models will be run by condition. For effects where condition alone is significant, repeated measures ANOVA will be used in follow-up models, with self-reported speech anxiety and self-reported speech performance as the dependent variable and condition as the independent variable. For models where there is a time-by-condition interaction, separate hierarchical linear models will be run for each condition, with self-reported speech anxiety and self-reported speech performance as the dependent variable, time as the fixed effect, and a random intercept per participant as the random effect.

We believe that certain demographic variables such as gender and race/ethnicity may affect the primary outcomes, given different social pressures to perform on speaking tasks. We will therefore perform exploratory analyses to examine the effects of these demographic variables on the primary, hypothesized effects of interest.

q25.value:
Cody, M. W., & Teachman, B. A. (2011). Global and local evaluations of public speaking performance in social anxiety. Behavior Therapy, 42, 601-611. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.beth.2011.01.004

Fydrich, T., Chambless, D. L., Perry, K. J., Buergener, F., & Beazley, M. B. (1998). Behavioral assessment of social performance: A rating system for social phobia. Behaviour Research and Therapy, 36, 995–1010. https://doi.org/10.1016/S0005-7967(98)00069-2

Gorlin, E. I., & Teachman, B. A. (2015). Threat interference biases predict socially anxious behavior: The role of inhibitory control and minute of stressor. Behavior Therapy, 46, 493-509. http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.beth.2015.03.001

Haahr, M. (1999). random.org: Introduction to Randomness and Random Numbers [vignette]. Retrieved from https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/random/vignettes/random-essay.pdf

Harb, G. C., Eng, W., Zaider, T., & Heimberg, R. G. (2003). Behavioral assessment of public-speaking anxiety using a modified version of the Social Performance Rating Scale. Behaviour Research and Therapy, 41, 1373-1380. http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/S0005-7967(03)00158-X

Hallion, L. S., & Ruscio, A. M. (2011). A meta-analysis of the effect of cognitive bias modification on anxiety and depression. Psychological Bulletin, 137(6), 940-958. https://doi.org/10.1037/a0024355

Namaky, N., Glenn, J. J., Eberle, J. W., & Teachman, B. A. (2019). Adapting cognitive bias modification to train healthy prospection. Manuscript submitted for publication.

Ouimet, A. J., Gawronski, B., & Dozois, D. J. (2009). Cognitive vulnerability to anxiety: A review and an integrative model. Clinical Psychology Review, 29(6), 459. http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.cpr.2009.05.004

Seligman, M. E. P., Railton, P., Baumeister, R. F., & Sripada, C. (2013). Navigating into the future or driven by the past. Perspectives on Psychological Science, 8(2), 119-141. http://dx.doi.org/10.1177/1745691612474317

P. H. Westfall, R. D. Tobias, D. Rom, R. D. Wolfinger, Y. Hochberg (1999). Multiple Comparisons and Multiple Tests Using the SAS System. Cary, NC: SAS Institute Inc.

registration_responses.q11: Self-reported speech anxiety and self-reported speech performance (see Measured Variables below) were stored in different tables than those used to store data analyzed by Namaky et al. (2019). Speech recordings were accessed by Jeremy Eberle and Nauder Namaky to confirm their availability, identify audiovisual issues, and determine the number of codeable videos per condition. A research assistant, different from the research assistants who coded the videos, trimmed excess footage from the videos before and after the speech. Eberle, Namaky, and at least two other research assistants will code videos from a different study for training purposes. These research assistants will code the videos from the present study, with Eberle and Namaky providing supervision and analyzing ratings for the purpose of maintaining inter-rater reliability.
registration_responses.q13: 776 participants completed the Expectancy Bias Task during screening, 240 enrolled and were randomized to condition, 201 began the first session, 172 completed all four sessions, and 109 completed the in-lab follow-up assessment. Eighty-two have codeable speech videos. We will analyze data from 109 participants for self-reported anxiety (expected and actual) and speech performance (expected and perceived). We will analyze data from 82 participants for observer-rated speech performance and avoidance behavior.
registration_responses.q14: We will include all of the data collected during the study. A power analysis based on the mean effect size from a meta-analysis of the effect of cognitive bias modification on interpretation bias (g = 0.81; Hallion & Ruscio, 2011) revealed that, using an alpha-level of .05, a comparable Cohen’s f of .40 would result in a 100% likelihood of finding significant condition differences with 50 participants per condition. We enrolled 60 participants per condition because we anticipated some dropout.
registration_responses.q20:
Condition: Condition will be dummy coded according to the contrasts outlined above.

Time: In affective forecasting analyses (see below), time will be coded with pre-speech ratings as 0 and post-speech ratings as 1.

All variables (except time) will be converted to standard scores (mean centered and divided by their respective standard deviations). This will be done to make effect sizes comparable between the models and to increase the likelihood of model convergence.
registration_responses.q21:
We will use an alpha level of .05 for determining significance. We will correct for multiple testing within each model using the method for family-wise correction outlined by Westfall et al. (1999). 

Exploratory models will also not be corrected for multiple comparison, in order to minimize the chance of false negatives. These findings will, therefore, be interpreted with caution and used to inform future, confirmatory studies.
registration_responses.q22: All participants with valid data will be included in the analysis. Valid data in the case of video coding means that a participant consented for video data to be used, and the video quality was such that the participant could be seen and heard by the raters. Valid data in the case of self-report data means that the participant answered the question when prompted.
registration_responses.q23: For item-level missingness on the MPSP, we will analyze the mean of the available items. If a participant did not complete any items of a given self-report measure, then they will not be included in the analysis of that measure. If a participant did not consent to the use of video data or was not visible or audible on their video, then they will not be included in the analysis of observer-rated speech performance.
registration_responses.q24:
To test our exploratory hypotheses concerning affective forecasting, we will use separate, hierarchical linear models for each dependent variable: self-reported speech anxiety and self-reported speech performance. Each of these variables will be a dependent variable in a model. Time, condition, and the time-by-condition interaction will be entered as fixed effects, and a random intercept per participant will be entered as the random effect. Independent variables will be considered sequentially in the model, with time and condition entered simultaneously at level 1 and their interaction entered at level 2. Level 1 results will only be analyzed in models with no significant time-by-condition interaction. The initial contrasts will compare all other groups to Neutral Control, but descriptive models will be run with each condition set as the reference group to characterize significant effects.

If any condition or time-by-condition effects are significant, follow-up models will be run by condition. For effects where condition alone is significant, repeated measures ANOVA will be used in follow-up models, with self-reported speech anxiety and self-reported speech performance as the dependent variable and condition as the independent variable. For models where there is a time-by-condition interaction, separate hierarchical linear models will be run for each condition, with self-reported speech anxiety and self-reported speech performance as the dependent variable, time as the fixed effect, and a random intercept per participant as the random effect.

We believe that certain demographic variables such as gender and race/ethnicity may affect the primary outcomes, given different social pressures to perform on speaking tasks. We will therefore perform exploratory analyses to examine the effects of these demographic variables on the primary, hypothesized effects of interest.

registration_responses.q8.question: Participants were randomized to either one of four conditions: Positive Prospection, Positive Prospection + Negation, 50/50, or Neutral Control. Participants were asked to complete two sessions per week for two weeks. Before starting the first session, participants were asked to complete, in random order, measures of expectancy bias, anxiety and depression symptoms, self-efficacy, growth mindset, and optimism. Participants were asked to complete the bias task, with the same stimuli, after every session except the first. Within one week after completing the fourth session, participants were asked to complete the follow-up, in which they completed the baseline measures again in random order. After completing these measures, they completed measures of their expected speech-related anxiety and expected speech performance and then measures of their actual anxiety and perceived speech performance following the speech.
registration_responses.q12.question: Students in the psychology department participant pool at a midatlantic university whose net expectancy bias scores (mean of positive bias items - mean of negative bias items) were more than 0.5 standard deviations below the mean of the sample (i.e., less than 1.11) and who were at least 18 years of age were eligible and invited by email to participate for course credit. The recruitment and data collection occurred between August 2015 and May 2016.
registration_responses.q16.question: The positive conditions presented emotionally ambiguous scenarios about the future that ended positively 100% of the time after first either negating a negative outcome (Positive Prospection + Negation) or not (Positive Prospection). The 50/50 condition presented emotionally ambiguous scenarios that ended positively 50% of the time and negatively 50% of the time. Neutral Control presented emotionally neutral scenarios. All conditions presented 48 scenarios per session.
registration_responses.q17.question:
Self-Reported Speech Anxiety
    Expected. Expected peak speech anxiety “during a 4-min speech that will be evaluated by a researcher” was assessed using the following 7-point Likert item ranging from 1 (not at all anxious) to 7 (totally anxious): “To what extent do you think you will experience anxiety during speech, when you feel the most anxious?”
    Actual. Actual peak speech anxiety “during the speech, at the height of [the] emotion” was assessed using the following 7-point Likert item ranging from 1 (not at all anxious) to 7 (totally anxious): “How anxious did you feel when you felt most anxious during the speech?”
    
Self-Reported Speech Performance
    Expected. Expected speech performance (“how you believe you will perform during the speech task based on a number of features”) was assessed with an adapted version of the Modified Perception of Speech Performance Questionnaire (MPSP; Cody & Teachman, 2011), a 12-item self-report of global and local speech performance features using 5-point Likert items ranging from 0 (not at all) to 4 (very much). Negative items will be reverse scored so that higher scores indicate better performance. We will analyze the mean of the items. Because the items are about expected speech performance, the tense of each item was changed accordingly from that used in Cody and Teachman (2011; e.g., “keeping eye contact” vs. “kept eye contact”).
    Perceived. Actual speech performance (“how you believe you actually performed during the speech task based on a number of features”) was assessed with the MPSP. As for expected speech performance, negative items will be reverse scored so that higher scores indicate better performance. We will analyze the mean of the items.

Observer-Rated Speech Performance. We will assess observer-related speech performance with an adapted version (Gorlin & Teachman, 2015) of Harb, Eng, Zaider, and Heimberg’s (2003) modified version of the Social Performance Rating Scale (SPRS; Fydrich, Chambless, Perry, Buergener, & Beazley, 1998). Coders will rate the quality of participants’ eye gaze, vocal tone, and speech flow on three 5-point Likert items ranging from 1 (very poor) to 5 (very good) and participants’ discomfort on a 5-point Likert item ranging from 1 (very high) to 5 (very low). We will analyze the mean of the items following Gorlin and Teachman (2015).

Avoidance Behavior. Avoidance behavior will be measured as the speech duration, defined as the number of seconds from the moment the research assistant gave the instruction to begin the speech to the end of the participant’s last word of the speech. We will operationalize avoidance behavior as fewer seconds spent on the speech.
registration_responses.q18.question:
Self-Reported Speech Performance. Following Cody and Teachman (2011), we analyzed the mean of the 12 items of the MPSP.

Observer-Rated Speech Performance. Following Gorlin and Teachman (2015) and Harb et al. (2003), we analyzed the mean of the four eye gaze, vocal tone, speech flow, and discomfort items as an overall anxious behavior index score.
registration_responses.q19.question:
We will test our hypotheses concerning the effect of condition on self-reported anxiety, self-reported speech performance, observer-rated speech performance, and avoidance behavior using linear regression models. In each model, the DV will consist of one variable of interest at one time point. The full list of DVs is as follows:

Expected speech anxiety
Peak speech anxiety
Expected speech performance
Perceived speech performance
Observer-rated speech performance
Avoidance behavior

The IV in each model will be condition, with specific contrasts set to test our hypotheses outlined above. The following contrasts will be used for all models:

Positive Prospection and Positive Prospection + Negation vs. Neutral Control (Hypothesis: "Participants in the positive conditions... will have lower expected and actual anxiety during the speech, higher expected and perceived speech performance, higher observer-rated speech performance... and less avoidance behavior... than those in the Neutral Control condition").

50/50 vs. Neutral Control (Hypothesis: "Participants in the 50/50 condition will have intermediate results.")

50/50 vs. Positive Prospection and Positive Prospection + Negation (Hypothesis: "Participants in the 50/50 condition will have intermediate results.")

Positive Prospection vs. Positive Prospection + Negation (Hypothesis: “We will compare the two positive conditions [Positive Prospection, Positive Prospection + Negation] but do not have directional hypotheses for this comparison; instead, we have competing hypotheses…”).
